messages.text:
Hi Everyone. I use `nvim` with the Julia LSP server (julials). Today, after not having been using it for a while, I noticed it stopped working. Changes I've made recently include:
• Updating `nvim`  (I have NVIM v0.5.0-dev+965-gd0668b36a installed).
• Removed the `diagnostic-nvim` plugin since it is deprecated and its features have been moved to nvim core. I followed this <https://github.com/nvim-lua/diagnostic-nvim/issues/73|migration guide> 
• Switched to Julia 1.5.3
This is the content of `lsp.log` :

elements.text: with the Julia LSP server (julials). Today, after not having been using it for a while, I noticed it stopped working. Changes I've made recently include:

messages.text:
People of <#CA8TYH0LU|vim>!
Whats your experience with kakoune and julia lsp?

elements.text:
!
Whats your experience with kakoune and julia lsp?

messages.text:
Hail and well met fellow traveler! :crossed_swords: Welcome to <#CA8TYH0LU|vim> <@U01AJUF2GEP> - sit by the :fire: and chat a while :beers: .

Regarding Julia LSP, I used it with Neovim 5 and found it extremely buggy. Decided not to engage with it too much as the autocompletion was not great and found it slowed down my workflow. It has great potential, but not something I can invest in right now.

elements.text: Hail and well met fellow traveler!

.

Regarding Julia LSP, I used it with Neovim 5 and found it extremely buggy. Decided not to engage with it too much as the autocompletion was not great and found it slowed down my workflow. It has great potential, but not something I can invest in right now.

messages.text:
re-posting from zulip:

I have some admittedly idiosyncratic preferences for my indentations.  In particular, I want all closing delimiters to occur at the start of new lines,  unless they enclose function arguments.

So, for example, currently if I write a closing delimiter on a new line I get, e.g.
```julia
Dict(:a=>1,
     :b=>2,
    )```
What I *want* is
```julia
Dict(:a=>1,
     :b=>2,
)```
For functions, what I get is
```julia
function f(x=1;
        kwarg1=2
    )
end```
but what I *want* is
```julia
function f(x=1;
           kwarg1=2
          )
end```
Anyone know what I can set to achieve this?  I figure the first one is probably easy
